factoid: When campaigning, Rostóv allowed himself the indulgence of riding not a regimental but a Cossack horse.
Rostóv was a judge of horses and a sportsman.
Rostóv had lately procured a large, fine, mettlesome Donéts horse.
The horse was dun-colored with a light mane and tail.
When Rostóv rode the horse, no one could outgallop him.
Riding the horse was a pleasure to Rostóv.
Rostóv thought of the horse, of the morning, of the doctor's wife.
Rostóv did not think of the impending danger.
Formerly, when going into action, Rostóv had felt afraid.
Now Rostóv had not the least feeling of fear.
Rostóv was fearless.
Rostóv was not fearless because he had grown used to being under fire.
Rostóv was not fearless because he had learned how to manage his thoughts when in danger.
Rostóv had grown accustomed to think about anything but the impending danger when going into action.
During the first period of his service, Rostóv had not been able to think about anything but the impending danger.
With time, Rostóv learned to think about anything but the impending danger.
Rostóv rode beside Ilyín under the birch trees.
Rostóv occasionally plucked leaves from a branch that met his hand.
Rostóv sometimes touched his horse’s side with his foot.
Rostóv handed a pipe he had finished to a hussar riding behind him without turning round.
Rostóv had a calm and careless air as though he were merely out for a ride.
Rostóv glanced with pity at the excited face of Ilyín.
Ilyín talked much and in great agitation.
Rostóv knew from experience the tormenting expectation of terror and death the cornet was suffering.
Rostóv knew that only time could help the cornet.
As soon as the sun appeared in a clear strip of sky beneath the clouds, the wind fell.
The wind fell as if it dared not spoil the beauty of the summer morning after the storm.
Drops continued to fall but vertically now.
All was still.
The whole sun appeared on the horizon.
The sun disappeared behind a long narrow cloud that hung above it.
A few minutes later the sun reappeared brighter from behind the top of the cloud, tearing its edge.
Everything grew bright and glittered.
The sound of guns came ahead of them with that light and as if in reply to it.
Before Rostóv had time to consider and determine the distance of the firing, Count Ostermann-Tolstóy’s adjutant came galloping from Vítebsk.
The adjutant had orders to advance at a trot along the road.
The squadron overtook the infantry and the battery.
The battery had quickened its pace.
The squadron rode down a hill.
The squadron passed through an empty and deserted village and then ascended again.
The horses began to lather.
The men began to flush.
The order of the regimental commander was heard ahead: “Halt! Dress your ranks!”.
The order from in front was: “Forward by the left. Walk, march!”.
The hussars passed along the line of troops on the left flank of our position.
The hussars halted behind our Uhlans who were in the front line.
Our infantry stood to the right in a dense column.
Our infantry were the reserve.
Higher up the hill on the very horizon, our guns were visible through the wonderfully clear air.
Our guns were brightly illuminated by slanting morning sunbeams.
In front beyond a hollow dale, the enemy’s columns and guns could be seen.
Our advanced line was already in action.
Our advanced line could be heard briskly exchanging shots with the enemy in the dale.
At these sounds, long unheard, Rostóv’s spirits rose.
The sounds were like the strains of the merriest music.
The shots cracked: trap-ta-ta-tap!
The shots cracked together and then several quickly one after another.
All was silent again.
It sounded again as if someone were walking on detonators and exploding them.
The hussars remained in the same place for about an hour.
A cannonade began.
Count Ostermann with his suite rode up behind the squadron.
Count Ostermann halted.
Count Ostermann spoke to the commander of the regiment.
Count Ostermann rode up the hill to the guns.
After Ostermann had gone, a command rang out to the Uhlans.
The command was: “Form column! Prepare to charge!”.
The infantry in front of the Uhlans departed into platoons to allow the cavalry to pass.
The Uhlans started.
The streamers on the Uhlans’ spears fluttered.
The Uhlans trotted downhill toward the French cavalry seen below to the left.
As soon as the Uhlans descended the hill, the hussars were ordered up the hill to support the battery.
As the hussars took the places vacated by the Uhlans, bullets came from the front.
The bullets were whining and whistling.
The bullets fell spent without taking effect.
